FacilityStr1: 9.3 miles south of New Town, ND

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program 1 Risk Management Plan

Mary R Smith Pad

WPX Energy Williston, LLC



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



A J-T plant designed to recover propane, butane and natural gasoline from gas prior to gathering and final treatment for WPX Energy, Inc. (WPX) is present at the Mary R. Smith 5-8H Pad.  This report provides the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the recovery skid system, pursuant to the requirements of the U.S. EPA RMP rule.



The system is designed to remove liquids from gas at the wellhead, having an inlet pressure between 150 and 400 psi.  The J-T valve system can generate temperatures as low as -20?F and is used to remove liquids from flared gases.  The portability of the unit allows it to easily be moved from site to site when flaring ceases.  The NGL storage tanks have an 18,000 gallon capacity. The leasing company operating the system will have one tank onsite which has a maximum fill of 14,400 gallons. The 14,400 gallons total is equivalent to 82,224 lbs. of flammable liquids.



Under the authority of section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act, the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions require facilities that produce, handle, process, distribute, or store certain chemicals to develop a Risk Management Program, prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP), and submit the RMP to EPA. Covered facilities were initially required to comply with the rule in 1999, and the rule has been amended on several occasions since then, most recently in 2004. This facility is regulated under Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68), more commonly known as the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. RMP plans must be prepared for processes that store in excess of the thresholds set forth by 40 CFR 68.130. For flammable liquids, the threshold is 10,000 lbs.  The leasing company can store approximately 82,224 lbs. of NGL and exceeds 10,000 lbs. threshold, thus the facility is subject to the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention rule and must prepare an RMP.



LOCA

TION



The Mary R Smith 5-8H Pad is located in the N ? of the NW ? of Section 5, Township 150N, Range 92W, Mountrail County, North Dakota, on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation (FBIR).



Latitude: 47.84696, Longitude: -102.48778



DRIVING DIRECTIONS



Proceed southerly from New Town, ND along College Drive. College Drive becomes 88th Ave NW. Follow this route for approximately 7.2 miles to the intersection of 32nd St NW. Turn left onto 32nd St NW and continue easterly for approximately 2.0 miles to the intersection of 86th Ave NW. Turn right onto 86th Ave NW and continue southerly for approximately 3.1 miles to the intersection of 29th St NW. Turn right onto 29th St NW. Continue westerly on 29th St NW for approximately 3.0 miles to an existing road to the north. Continue northerly and easterly for approximately 1.1 miles to the existing access road to the pad. Turn right onto access road to the existing well location. 

DISPERSION MODELING ANALYSIS WITH RMP*COMP



RMP*Comp: Results of Consequence Analysis

Scenario Summary

September 20, 2018



Chemical Name                    CAS Number    Quantity Released (pounds)

Butane                       106-97-8    18966

Ethane                             74-84-0    5521

Isobutane [Propane, 2-methyl]     75-28-5    5827

Isopentane [Butane, 2-methyl-]     78-78-4    5898

Methane                             74-82-8    113

Pentane                       109-66-0    10119

Propane                             74-98-6    36780



Threat type:      Flammable



Scenario type:  Worst-case



Release type:   Vapor Cloud Explosion

Estimated distance to 1 psi overpressure: 0.3 miles (0.6 kilometers)



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS: POPULATION AND ENVIRONMENT



After the distance to the flammable endpoint has been determined, the offsite impacts on population, public receptors, and environmental receptors should be analyzed as required by the RMP rule. The population within a circle centered at the point of release and a radius equal to the distance to the flammable e

ndpoint should be estimated to two significant digits. In addition, all types of public receptors (schools, residences, hospitals, prisons, public recreation areas or arenas, major commercial or industrial areas) and environmental receptors (national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, or refuges; federal wilderness areas) within this distance should be identified.



A field survey was used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the flammable endpoint and to identify public receptors.  The survey showed that no population is within the 0.3 mile impact radius for the worst case release. The impact area on a map is demonstrated in appendix A. The types of public receptors and environmental receptors identified within the impact area are listed in Table 2-2.  Google Earth was used to find the public receptors within the impact radius. Additionally, no environmental receptors are impacted by the worst-case release scenario.
